repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Expanding Microfinance
            Outreach and Improving Sustainability Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Expanding Microfinance
            Outreach and Improving Sustainability Project for
            Afghanistan were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            unsatisfactory, the risk to development outcome was high,
            the Bank performance was moderately satisfactory, and the
            Borrower performance was also moderately satisfactory. Some
            lessons learned included: as a precautionary measure in
            fragile countries it may be a good idea to provide
            additional support to the qualified apex institution in
            determining eligibility of partner financial institutions
            due to changing dynamics in the financial sector. Security
            is a significant factor to consider for the viability of
            micro or Small or Medium Enterprise (SME) lending. As
            demonstrated in Afghanistan, the security situation can have
            a direct negative impact on portfolio quality. As a result,
            careful assessment should be made prior to rolling out
            operations in less secure areas. It is interesting to note
            that the only Microfinance Service Provider (MFP) that is
            operationally and commercially sustainable is First
            Microfinance Bank (FMFB), which is also a commercial bank,
            registered in line with banking regulations, and as such
            subject to all relevant prudential norms and related supervision.

16235781.projn:
AF-Expanding Microfinance Outreach And
            Improving Sustainability -- P104301
16235781.majtheme: Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion,Financial and private sector development

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Expanding Microfinance
            Outreach and Improving Sustainability Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Expanding
            Microfinance Outreach and Improving Sustainability Project
            for Afghanistan is to achieve operational sustainability for
            most microfinance service providers (MFPs) and help them
            scale up outreach of financial services to meet the demands
            and needs of many poor Afghans, especially women. This
            restructuring paper seeks approval to extend the closing
            date of the International Development Association (IDA)
            Grant for the project from December 31, 2011 to June 30,
            2012. This second extension, bringing the cumulative
            extension period to 18 months, is required to provide
            adequate time to complete the remaining project activities
            and thus allow full completion of the project development
            objective (PDO). The activities have been delayed due to
            several factors, some of which have been outside the control
            of the project implementing agency, Microfinance Investment
            Support Facility for Afghanistan (MISFA).

Afghanistan - Expanding
            Microfinance Outreach and Improving Sustainability Project :
            restructuring (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

13768228.projn:
AF-Expanding Microfinance Outreach And
            Improving Sustainability -- P104301
13768228.majtheme: Financial and private sector development,Rural development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!:
Afghanistan - Expanding Microfinance
            Outreach and Improving Sustainability Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The Expanding Microfinance Outreach and
            Improving Sustainability Project restructuring is for an
            extension of the closing date of the International
            Development Association (IDA) grant from December 31, 2010
            to December 31, 2011 to enable Microfinance Investment
            Support Facility for Afghanistan (MISFA) to complete the
            ongoing consolidation exercise and support MFIs to improves
            sustainability of their operations. The one year extension
            is based on: (i) MISFA's improved project management,
            including being proactive and taking bold steps to improve
            performance of microfinance institutions (MFIs); (ii) the
            need to ensure that the microfinance sector continues to
            grow and support more Afghans in both urban and rural areas,
            and (iii)  the critical need for the Bank to stay engaged
            with the implementing agency to ensure that public funds
            that have been invested by donors and government in the MFIs
            are judiciously utilized to achieve project objectives.

            Microfinance Outreach and Improving Sustainability Project :
